Thanks for your interests in our products. In these documents, you could find out how to use the SDK provided by DJI and lead your aircraft to finish a series of tasks automatically and systematically.

Before you get start, we would like to briefly introduce the components of the SDK, which respectively represents the components of the drone. In our SDK, DJIDrone class is the brain of the SDK. This class connects each component, interchanges information with them and commands them. DJIBattery, the source power of the drone, should be seriously concerned since if the battery level is low, the drone will terminate all of the tasks and go home directly. Hence, we recommend that developers should plan and test their schedule of flight tasks. By using the DJICamera, you could find out another angle for viewing the world. As the eyes of the Drone, we develop some operations for DJICamera. With the help of this operations, you may find out some specific beauties of the world, which are only from the sky. The DJIMedia would maintain the information of photos and records. What is more, if you want to plan the tasks for drones, you may find out how convenient the ground station is. We provide on-key-fly, on-key-gohome and tasks schedule. However, SDK of Ground Station requires developers have SDK-LEVEL-2 key (you could send e-mail and ask for upgrading your SDK LEVEL). Finally, good pilots need to analyze the data of each flight so that they could further improve their skill. Hence, we provide DJIMainController for the developer so that they could investigate the instance message from the drone.

Since the app and drone are distributed, there should be some callbacks for confirming whether the commands are received or for confirming the execution result. Thus, in DJI SDK, we provide a series of callback functions for communicating instance message and for receiving the execution results. Most of callback functions, which are asynchronous, are without any input parameters and the tasks of communication will be finished by their own onResult() functions. The lack of information will lead confusion for the developers. Therefore, in SDK document, each of the callback will be presented with their onResult() input parameter(s).

Furthermore, DJI SDK will build connection between drone and app on Android. To make sure the information interchange is stable and completed, the lifecycle of callback should be set correctly. Effected by the android life cycle, the callback, especially the one receives the information from the aircraft, should follow the pattern of android system and update its statement on the basis of the stage of the life cycle. For better understanding the construction of the life cycle of DJI callback, we will provide a tutorial for setting up the callback life cycle. The code follow is a sample of life cycle setting of DJIBatteryUpdateInfoCallBack.

Life cycle.

Private DJIBatteryUpdateInfoCallBack mBattryUpdateInfoCallBack = null;

Protected void onCreate(Bundle saveInstanceState){
 /* other statements */
 mBatteryUpdateInfoCallBack = new DJIBatteryUpdateInfoCallBack(){
  public void onResult(DJIBatteryProperty state){
   public void run(){

   }
 }
}

DJIDrone.getDjiBattery().setBatteryUpdateInfoCallBack(mBatteryUpdateInfoCallBack);
}

Protected void onResume(){
 /* other statements */
 DJIDrone.getDjiBattery().startUpdateTimer(2000);
}

Protected void onPause(){
 /* other statements */
 DJIDrone.getDjiBattery().stopUpdateTimer();
}

Protected void onDestroy() {
 /* other statements */
 DJIDrone.getDjiCamera().setReceivedVideoDataCallBack(null);
}

We will provide tutorial for setting the life cycle in the one need it. We recommend that before getting start, developers should set the life cycle correctly so that there will not be any conflicts.

Finally, the SDK documentation will be updated and improved continuously. For example, some of the functions will be renamed or be transported to other class. For compatibility, we designed an obsolete list for the old APIs so that the old APIs could be invoked by the apps which have been develop before SDK's updating. However, we recommend the developer should use the up-to-date SDK to develop their app because the new SDK would have a better construction.

The table following is the obsolete list which will contain the information about which APIs have been updated.
